faqs.question: Who is David Lopis and what is his background in AI and mental health?
faqs.answer: David is an Australian registered psychologist, AI consultant, and board‑approved supervisor. He leads Psychology Squared (3,500+ clinicians) and has presented/trained with APS, AAPi, and ACPA. Learn more on Services.

faqs.question: Do you provide services outside Australia or virtually?
faqs.answer: Yes. Virtual/online sessions are available. In‑person and hybrid formats can be arranged depending on needs.

faqs.question: What kinds of services do you offer?
faqs.answer:
• Individual AI consultation
• Group training and workshops
• Speaking engagements and keynotes
• AI Compliance Pack (templates and guidance)
• Company collaborations (product reviews and ongoing assistance)
See Services and Compliance Pack.

faqs.question: What information do I need to provide when booking?
faqs.answer: Name, email, organisation, role, expected group size, preferred dates, budget (optional), location/format (in‑person/virtual/hybrid), and any specific topics or additional info. You can start from our booking options.

faqs.question: Do you offer tailored workshops for different professional groups?
faqs.answer: Yes. Examples include AI Basics for Clinicians, AI for Social Workers, and Social Media & AI for Psychologists. Sessions are tailored to your context.

faqs.question: What topics do you cover in talks and workshops?
faqs.answer: Getting started with AI in practice, ethical use and governance, AI tool demonstrations, social media and AI for psychologists, and discipline‑specific trainings.

faqs.question: Do you consult with companies on product development and positioning?
faqs.answer: Yes. Our Product Review includes tool trial, debrief, 1‑month follow‑up, and written recommendations. Ongoing Assistance covers planning, implementation, governance, and risk management. See Company Consulting and Collaborations.

faqs.question: Do you do keynotes at conferences?
faqs.answer: Yes. Examples include APS, AAPi, ACPA events, and ASAICP Symposium 2025. See Speaking & Events.

faqs.question: Where can I hear or watch your interviews and presentations?
faqs.answer:
• Mastering Therapy Podcast: “Using AI in Your Therapy Practice (Part 2)”
• YouTube: “ChatGPT and Beyond: AI’s Impact on Psychology”
Links on Media & Interviews.

faqs.question: Is there a community I can join to learn about AI in psychology?
faqs.answer: Yes. Join the “Australian Psychology AI Community” Facebook group. See Contact Information.

faqs.question: What is AI for clinicians, and how is it used in psychology?
faqs.answer: AI in clinical settings typically involves the use of technology through a computer or phone, usually via a web browser, to help clinicians work more efficiently and make use of research to better support clients. One of the most common applications is through AI scribes, which reduce the workload associated with writing notes and reports by automating an initial draft and assisting clinicians in finalizing it quickly. Tasks that once took 10 to 20 minutes can now be completed in just a few minutes, while reports that previously took hours can often be finished within 15 to 45 minutes, depending on their complexity. Beyond documentation, AI is also being used to leverage research for deeper client understanding and more effective therapeutic support.

faqs.question: What are some of the examples of AI uses within therapy sessions specifically?
faqs.answer: AI scribes are one of the most common tools, with examples including Heidi, Practaluma, ANSA, NovoNote, and several others that can be found on the comparison table. Other emerging uses include therapy bots or AI companions, where individuals may interact directly with the tool, though this raises important ethical and professional considerations. AI is also being used to generate graphics that assist in developing social stories or visual aids for clients, as well as to create diagrams, videos, and audio materials. A wide range of new applications is emerging, and our understanding of these tools continues to evolve over time.

faqs.question: How can ChatGPT help psychologists in daily clinical work?
faqs.answer: ChatGPT should not be used for client work that involves sensitive or protected client information, as it is important to avoid using tools that are not compliant with privacy and security requirements. However, it can be a valuable tool for other purposes, such as understanding different clinical presentations, developing schedules, creating workshops, building psychoeducation resources, and supporting business development. ChatGPT offers a practical introduction to AI and serves as a foundational tool for clinicians who want to build their understanding of how AI can support their professional work.

faqs.question: How do you address ethics?
faqs.answer: We align with the Australian AI Ethics principles and professional competencies, emphasising transparency, accountability, privacy, and safety. See AI Ethical Standards.

faqs.question: What is the AI Compliance Pack?
faqs.answer: A ready‑to‑use set of templates and guidance drafted by PGC Legal Pty Ltd: AI Policy, Privacy Policy, Consent Form for AI use, Implementation Checklist, and transcript inclusion guidance. Instant access after purchase. See AI Compliance Pack.

faqs.question: Who is the AI Compliance Pack for?
faqs.answer: Psychologists using or planning to use AI. Individual licence is $199 (inc GST); practice bundles available on request.

faqs.question: Is the Compliance Pack legal advice? What are the limitations?
faqs.answer: The content is informational, not legal advice, and comes with limitations of liability. Using it does not create a solicitor‑client relationship. See Important Legal Information.

faqs.question: Do you compare AI tools for clinicians?
faqs.answer: Yes. See our overview of AI scribe companies, including features, pricing, and trials on Comparisons.
